results.title: Men, machines and the secretary
results.creator_credit: Bill Young, Ian Rosenbloom and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Systems Organisation the Management of Complexity”.
Examines the London headquarters of Texaco, a multi-national oil company, to case study the introduction of word processors which demanded a major reorganisation of the company’s use of secretaries.

results.title: The Company computers and the unions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Systems Organisation the Management of Complexity”.
This film was made at the Pearl Assurance Company where recent developments in office technology, specifically microcomputers, is beginning to have a dramatic impact on the kinds of work that the staff at Pearl produce.

group_works.title: The Sprint crawl
group_works.creator_credit: Dr Frank Ryan and Ryan Films

results.title: The Sprint crawl
results.creator_credit: Dr Frank Ryan and Ryan Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Swimming Instruction”.
A close study of the competitive swimming stroke, “the sprint crawl”. With the aid of diagrams and slow-motion photography, the film analyses the action of the arm stroke, the leg kick, the pool-edge turning and the initial diving.
results.description:

results.title: Proper summer bush clothing
results.creator_credit: Norman Keziere, Hugh Moreland and Moreland-Latchford Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Survival in the Wilderness”.
Two boys head off on a fishing trip, one wearing correct clothing, and the other, ordinary light summer weight slacks and shirt. As the film progresses, the viewer sees that proper clothing is essential to one’s comfort and well-being when camping out.

results.title: Proper winter clothing
results.creator_credit: Norman Keziere, James McCormick and Moreland-Latchford Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Survival in the Wilderness”.
Skiers, hikers and other winter outdoor people learn quickly that it is not how much you have on but what you wear and how you wear it. this film provides the necessary clues to keeping you warm during outdoor travel in winter.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Norman Keziere, James McCormick and Moreland-Latchford Productions

results.title: Imants Tillers
results.creator_credit: Andrew Scollo, Robert Lindsay, Michael Bongiovanni and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)”.
Imants Tillers along with Peter Myers and Peter Rees use the example of Bankstown, New South Wales to discuss the constructed and artificial landscape in terms of Australian culture and the relationship between art making and suburbinisation. Bankstown is a town constructed on landfill. It epitomises and celebrates the ‘height’ of suburban aesthetic values. Tillers, Myers and Rees explore themes of the ‘fulfilled suburban dream’, the suburban ‘visual’ language, Australian Futurism in architecture. Bankstown is the quintessential Australian suburb in its exuberance to express and celebrate urban pride. Some interesting observations are made along the way. The houses are: locked within parameters of essential design elements, with identical floor plans and no fence lines that allow each house to sit like artwork on walls for display reinstituting the notion of ‘promenade’. [PRINT IS A DUB-COPY]
results.creator_credit_for_label: Andrew Scollo, Robert Lindsay, Michael Bongiovanni and Open Channel Productions

results.title: On Paper
results.creator_credit: Ray Harris, Michael Bongiovanni, Andrew Scollo, Robert Lindsay, National Gallery of Victoria and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)”.
The connecting link in this video is photography, and the different approaches Micky Allan, Sally Robinson, Mandy Martin and Jenny Watson have to producing works on paper using photography either directly or indirectly
